review.title: The Opacity of Backbones
review.abstract: A backbone of a boolean formula $F$ is a collection $S$ of its variables for which there is a unique partial assignment $a_S$ such that $F[a_S]$ is satisfiable [MZK+99,WGS03]. This paper studies the nontransparency of backbones. We show that, under the widely believed assumption that integer factoring is hard, there exist sets of boolean formulas that have obvious, nontrivial backbones yet finding the values, $a_S$, of those backbones is intractable. We also show that, under the same assumption, there exist sets of boolean formulas that obviously have large backbones yet producing such a backbone $S$ is intractable. Further, we show that if integer factoring is not merely worst-case hard but is frequently hard, as is widely believed, then the frequency of hardness in our two results is not too much less than that frequency.

sections.text: ar Xiv: 160 6.03 634v 4 [cs.A I] + 99, WGS03]. This paper examines the lack of transparency of backbones. We show that under the widespread assumption that integer factoring is hard, there are sets of Boolean formulas that have obvious, non-trivial backbones, but the values aS, these backbones are hard to find. We also show that under the same assumption, there are sets of Boolean formulas that obviously have large backbones, but still produce such a backbone S. Further, we show that the frequency of hardness in our two results is not too much lower than this frequency when integer factoring is not just a worst-case hard, but often hard, as is widely assumed.

sections.heading: 2 Results
sections.text: In Section 2.1 we will formulate our results without focusing on the density. In Section 2.2 we will then discuss how the hardness frequency of sets of the type we are discussing is related to that of sets in NP-coNP with the highest hardness frequencies. This section focuses only on the presentation of the results and their significance. We will provide evidence in Section 3.

sections.heading: 3.2 Proof Sketches for Section 2.2
sections.text: We will deal with this section briefly and informally, as we will argue that its assertions can be taken as follows from the evidence of the previous section. Crucially, the mapping of strings x (whether they belong to B) to the string that inserts x in A is (a) polynomial-temporal calculable (and therefore the one string that inserts x in A is at most polynomially longer than x) and (b) one-to-one. Any collection of m instances up to a certain length n that deceive a certain polynomial-temporal algorithm for B is thus associated with at least m unique instances in A altogether at most nq (where the polynomial bound to the length of the formula that inserts x in A means that it is at most nq3 long). Thus, if an algorithm for "A" had been set so that the algorithm had at most m "errors on strings up to the length nq, it would certainly have an algorithm form of up to the length of most nq3.

sections.heading: 4 Related Work
sections.text: In fact, the fact is that most of them are able to assert themselves, that they are able to assert themselves, and that they are able to assert themselves, and that they are able to assert themselves, that they are able to assert themselves, that they are able to assert themselves, and that they are able to assert themselves.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusions
sections.text: We argued under assumptions that are widely believed to be true, such as the hardness of integer factors, that knowledge of the existence of a large backbone does not mean that one can efficiently find a large backbone, and finding a non-trivial backbone does not mean one can efficiently find its value. Furthermore, we showed that one can ensure that these effects are not very rare, but that they can occur with "almost" the same frequency as the error rates of the most densely defined hard sets in NP coNP coNP. Most of our results were based on the assumption that P 6 = NP-coNP, which is probably true, because if it is false, then integral factoring falls into P and the RSA encryption scheme. However, it would be interesting to see if one can obtain any (probably weaker) backbone opacity results under the weaker assumption that P 6 NP =. We did this, but let's consider these results to be particularly unsatisfactory and unsatisfactory.

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: We are deeply grateful to anonymous AAI-17 reviewers for very helpful comments and suggestions.

metadata.abstractText: A backbone of a boolean formula F is a collection S of its variables for which there is a unique partial assignment aS such that F [aS ] is satisfiable [MZK 99,WGS03]. This paper studies the nontransparency of backbones. We show that, under the widely believed assumption that integer factoring is hard, there exist sets of boolean formulas that have obvious, nontrivial backbones yet finding the values, aS , of those backbones is intractable. We also show that, under the same assumption, there exist sets of boolean formulas that obviously have large backbones yet producing such a backbone S is intractable. Further, we show that if integer factoring is not merely worst-case hard but is frequently hard, as is widely believed, then the frequency of hardness in our two results is not too much less than that frequency.
